docs.lead_paragraph: IT is common experience, when reading or hearing about an especially wonderful meal, to salivate at the thought of eating it. But for millions of Americans even the act of eating such a meal does not stimulate the release of salivary fluid. They suffer from dry mouth, a symptom often dismissed as an annoyance they have to learn to live with. Dry mouth is not just annoying. It can be extremely debilitating, interfering with the ability to taste food and swallow it, to talk and to maintain the health of the teeth and of oral tissues. It can also be a symptom of an underlying disorder of the immune system, Sjogren's syndrome, which affects fluid-secreting glands throughout the body.
docs.snippet: IT is common experience, when    reading or hearing about an   especially wonderful meal, to   salivate at the thought of eating it. But for millions of Americans even the act of eating such a meal does not stimulate the release of salivary fluid....

docs.lead_paragraph: A new internal investigative report does not support allegations that an Army anesthesiology chief performed drug tests on unconscious patients without their prior approval on behalf of the A. H. Robins Company, But the June 1 report by the Army inspector general's office concluded that the doctor, Col. Robert Watson, did test a breathing device produced by another company on one unconscious patient without permission. The device, an endotracheal tube, was manufactured by the Medi-Dyne Company, it said. The report does not mention A. H. Robins, based in Richmond, in connection with testing on unconscious patients at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center.
